rev.diff:
Line 47: Line 47:
The police reported that Saeed suffocated in an attempt to swallow a packet of [[hashish]], a claim supported by two autopsy reports made by Forensic Authorities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/52970|title=Journalists protest state media coverage of Alexandria police killing|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2010-06-230|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref> The police further stated that Saeed was "wanted for theft and weapons possession and that he resisted arrest."<ref name="CNN">{{cite news |title=Demonstrators in Egypt rail against brutality, man's death |author=Ben Wedeman |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-06-25/world/egypt.police.beating_1_brutality-mohamed-elbaradei-egyptian?_s=PM:WORLD |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=June 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 3, 2011}}</ref>
The police reported that Saeed suffocated in an attempt to swallow a packet of [[hashish]], a claim supported by two autopsy reports made by Forensic Authorities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/52970|title=Journalists protest state media coverage of Alexandria police killing|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2010-06-230|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref> The police further stated that Saeed was "wanted for theft and weapons possession and that he resisted arrest."<ref name="CNN">{{cite news |title=Demonstrators in Egypt rail against brutality, man's death |author=Ben Wedeman |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-06-25/world/egypt.police.beating_1_brutality-mohamed-elbaradei-egyptian?_s=PM:WORLD |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=June 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 3, 2011}}</ref>
â
Former chief medical examiner of Egypt, Ayman Fouda, was interviewed about the proper procedure that should have been followed for Saeed's autopsy. He stated that the "mechanics of the injuries" that Saeed had sustained should have been investigated and his brain should have also been tested to see whether he had had a concussion, as the medical examiner that had conducted the autopsy had done neither.<ref>{{cite news |title=Interview: Former chief medical examiner on Khaled Saeed autopsy |author=Dareen Farghaly |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/53003y |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
+
Former chief medical examiner of Egypt, Ayman Fouda, was interviewed about the proper procedure that should have been followed for Saeed's autopsy. He stated that the "mechanics of the injuries" that Saeed had sustained should have been investigated and his brain should have also been tested to see whether he had had a concussion, as the medical examiner that had conducted the autopsy had done neither.<ref>{{cite news |title=Interview: Former chief medical examiner on Khaled Saeed autopsy |author=Dareen Farghaly |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/53003 |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
The two police officers were later jailed for four days pending questioning on beatings that they allegedly carried out on Saeed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/egyptian-protesters-see-policemen-s-jailing-in-activist-s-death-as-a-victory-1.649353|title=Egyptian protesters see policemen's jailing in activist's death as a victory|publisher=[[Gulf News]]|date=2010-07-02|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref> Saeed's family members stated that Saeed's death was "tortured to death for possessing video material that implicates members of the police in a drug deal."<ref>{{cite news |title=Police killing sparks Egypt protest |author= |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201061415530298271.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera English |date=June 14, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
The two police officers were later jailed for four days pending questioning on beatings that they allegedly carried out on Saeed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/egyptian-protesters-see-policemen-s-jailing-in-activist-s-death-as-a-victory-1.649353|title=Egyptian protesters see policemen's jailing in activist's death as a victory|publisher=[[Gulf News]]|date=2010-07-02|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref> Saeed's family members stated that Saeed's death was "tortured to death for possessing video material that implicates members of the police in a drug deal."<ref>{{cite news |title=Police killing sparks Egypt protest |author= |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201061415530298271.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera English |date=June 14, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
